posts.name: Kade Dressing
posts.cooked: After this season, we were not satisfied with our wiring and aim to improve it for future competitions. We wanted to understand how others manage wiring efficiently while keeping it visually appealing. Our current setup involves using heat shrink tubing to connect wires and prevent entanglement. However, whenever a CAN (Controller Area Network) issue arises, accessing the problematic area becomes cumbersome and time-consuming. Additionally, certain wires become tangled, necessitating the use of connectors like those from WAGO. We explored alternatives such as nylon wraps, hoping they would offer better durability. Unfortunately, an inspector at a previous competition mentioned specific types of wire that are harder to handle compared to the outdated ones we've been using. If anyone has insights or knows the exact type of wire referenced, we'd appreciate their guidance.

link_counts.title: Under‑performing our capabilities, Looking for Advice

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: We used heat shrink to keep moving wires connected, but encountering CAN issues required cutting into them, which was very time-consuming. Split loom sleeving proved to be an excellent solution for us this season.

posts.name: Kade Dressing
posts.cooked: The product is a braided split wire loom wrap cable sleeve tube harness lot sheathing management organize, designed for 3/8"-15ft. It is available on Amazon.com in the Electronics category and retails for $18.99.

posts.name: Brandon
posts.cooked: We use the split wire looms and zip ties.

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked:
Looks like it'll work great to me. This product, available on Amazon, features a 25-foot-long protector sleeve designed to shield cords, cables, and audio/video connections. It comes in black and is suitable for protecting against chewing, suitable for USB power cords, audio-video cables, and other similar uses. The product is crafted from durable materials, ensuring reliable protection and durability.  

This particular listing offers a slightly discounted price compared to others, but both options perform exceptionally well.

posts.name: Kade Dressing
posts.cooked:
Sure! Here's the cleaned-up version of your text:

"Awesome, thank you!"

We used heavy cable sleeving this year for our competition robot. The specific product we chose is suitable for small wires like those used in CAN networks (18AWG power to CAN coders, pigeons, etc). This cable sleeving helps keep wires organized and protected. Additionally, we highly recommend learning to solder for CAN and 18AWG cables, as it eliminates the need for large connectors and improves overall system reliability. For better organization, we use zipties to bundle cables together, and we always strain relieve wires to prevent them from becoming unplugged. For example, our cable runs are all zip-tied together to support each other and keep everything aligned. We also recently acquired new wire from PowerWerx, and we've been impressed with their quality and flexibility. Lastly, Anderson Powerpoles are excellent, especially when paired with zipties around the connector holes.

posts.name: Kade Dressing
posts.cooked: We switched to soldering our CANs together due to issues with the wagos during Belton. They were soldered for our San Antonio and State events, but why not go with 12 AWG instead?

posts.name: Nick Foote
posts.cooked:
Here is the cleaned-up version of the provided text, formatted into a single coherent paragraph while maintaining the original meaning and structure:

---

We had to continuously use multiple sections of wire because we didn’t have long rolls. Everyone’s focusing on the split loom nylon protectors, which is absolutely the right move. However, this is a major issue. Adding multiple points of failure in your wire setup is causing extra complications. Unfortunately, this led to waste during matches due to having to cut wire repeatedly. 

To avoid this in the future, we recommend purchasing longer CAN wires instead of shorter ones. We’ve since redone our wiring and connectors, and you can find details about our switch to rally sport wires [here](https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/2102-build-thread-2024-25-open-alliance/476375/3). Over two years, we’ve never experienced a wiring issue in competition. As for soldering, it’s effective, but it requires skill. Students often run into trouble with poor solder joints, which can be frustrating because detecting issues isn’t straightforward.

--- 

This version removes all unnecessary HTML elements, retains key information, and preserves readability.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Nick Foote - 2102 Team Paradox - Engineering Mentor and Founding Student

posts.name: Kade Dressing
posts.cooked:
We faced several problems during the project, including difficulties with soldering and relying on outdated components like ferrel connectors and wagos. One of the main reasons we struggled to obtain sufficient lengths of wire was due to our limited resources and reliance on the previous year’s members for support.

Our prior year members were not proactive in exploring new solutions. For example, our old programming lead had difficulty coding the robot independently and often relied on existing code from other teams. Additionally, our build team frequently made mistakes by using templates rather than custom designs, resulting in faulty wiring and components. The cost of wiring was kept low due to limited funding and the lack of focus on improving wiring quality.

This year, I took on the role of programming lead and gained nearly all the knowledge needed to ensure our team would succeed. I shared this knowledge with my teammates, but the lack of preparation from the previous year’s members led to poor tracking of tasks and equipment failure. As a result, we consistently ran out of necessary materials, such as wires and computers, due to the lengthy approval process from the district. Each time we needed supplies, we had to request permission, which took two weeks, delaying our progress significantly. Additionally, by the time we finally received approval, many of our older components were sold out, leaving us unable to meet our goals.

To address these challenges, I’ve been working to reorganize our electrical components and improve our wiring practices. I’ve decided to limit the number of wire strands between motors and components and will use nylon wraps to store them safely. While this approach has helped, I acknowledge it wasn’t perfect and strive to learn from past mistakes.

posts.name: Nick Foote
posts.cooked:
Certainly! Here's the cleaned-up version of the text:

---

I’m sorry to hear you’ve been through so much trouble. Purchasing is definitely one of the most painful processes any team goes through. For many years, I’ve just been buying things for the team, thinking it’s not worth the hassle unless it’s significantly expensive. However, this year, I made a purchase that was worth being reimbursed for, but involving a school foundation and ASB added considerable difficulty.

For your team, buying a spool of nice wire costing between $50 and $100 makes sense because each match can cost over $400 to compete in, and losing in a match is a waste of that investment. It’s essential to start purchasing as much as possible in the fall, regardless of the season, due to the time it takes to procure items. Just remember to use Controller Area Network (CAN) wire wherever possible.

I hope this helps with procuring new wires and electronics.

Here’s a hint about setting up the driver station: ask a sponsor if they have any usable laptops, especially those that aren’t Windows 11 compatible. Just don’t share details about the computer with the school; it shouldn’t be locked down. After all, I prefer to break school rules that I find nonsensical and unrelated to safety concerns.

--- 

This version maintains the original meaning, removes unnecessary elements, and uses standard grammar and punctuation while preserving the intended tone.

posts.cooked: I think we’ve finally got some new CAN Controller Area Network wire coming in—maybe around 25 feet, but we might get more. For the computer, we were already planning on getting one from [friend's company](https://www.chiefdelphi.com/images/emoji/google/joy.png). My dad’s friend owns a company and he sponsors us, and he was willing to buy us a whole new computer—but something came up and he couldn’t fund it anymore. So, we’ll have to see what else we can find. As for breaking school rules, I’m definitely the same way as you—those rules just don’t make much sense to me.

posts.name: Dave Morrison
posts.cooked:
Here is the cleaned-up version of the text:

"What problems did you have with your CAN+ wago setup? Last year, we installed one without any issues. We ensured the use of proper gauge ferrules (22ga), essential due to the thin wire. The wire must be strain-relieved. A common mistake was not connecting the wire entirely to the ferrule. This year, we switched to Molex-SL connectors, which require slightly more skill and effort but offer a simpler connection process with minimal difference in performance."

posts.name: Olivia
posts.cooked: To connect power pole connectors, what type of zip ties do you recommend? While zips work well, they may be too large for the connector openings.

posts.name: bgg
posts.cooked: We used solder seal wire connectors for the first time this year, and they will likely be incorporated into our robots in the future. These connectors were mainly utilized for establishing short CAN (Controller Area Network) segments for each motor controller as an added precaution, ensuring the entire network remains operational even if a single component fails. Over three events, we experienced zero CAN-related issues. Additionally, I recommend upgrading to the Thrifty Nova CAN cables if you're using SPARK MAX. Lastly, the robot had hot glue applied to every connector that connects to it; however, this does not pose any problems as it easily comes off with alcohol.

posts.name: Jai Gupta
posts.cooked: We love using adhesive cable tie mounts, McMaster slit corrugated tubing, and braided sleeving. Additionally, during the design phase, we plan wire routing so that our designs remain electrically friendly, incorporating cable tie mounts into 3D printed parts. This approach enables us to efficiently wire everything, with clear, step-by-step instructions for prep operations—such as one end crimped, one end uncrimped with slack—for each wire.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: I also am a big fan of Anderson Powerpoles, especially when you put a ziptie through the holes in the connector to zip-tie them together, making it bulletproof. The Powerpole Pins make this even better, and I love powerpoles so much for this application because the pins make swapping quicker while maintaining strength surpassing a small ziptie.

link_counts.title: Amazon.com: Powerwerx PCLIP Retention Clips for PP15/30/45 Anderson Power Powerpole Connectors (25 pieces) : Electronics

posts.name: Nick Foote
posts.cooked: You don’t need to go through the tiny holes; just go around the whole thing (and between the wires), and you can use reasonably sized zip ties.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Nick Foote - 2102 Team Paradox - Engineering Mentor and Founding Student

posts.cooked:
We also need a new computer, but the district won’t let us get one unless they put administrative protection on it, which removes our access to use the driver station and other tools, so we have to use our current device instead.

If you really need to, maybe you can ask your tech department to allow you to connect on specific ports and IP addresses, and grant admin access on the driver station (for home development purposes, you should use a laptop with full admin access).

An example could involve the tech team enabling access to:
- 10.TE.AM.AMCircuit (the typical IP range for the RoboRIO, Radio, and most co-processors),
- 172.22.11.2 (the RoboRIO USB IP), 
- Port 22 for SSH access,
and refer to the game manual for further details at https://frctools.com/2025/rule/R704.

This setup, though not ideal, allows using a more powerful laptop for development and a regular laptop for coding.
We just use small zip ties that fit in the hole, but wrapping it around also works. As long as you just have zipties you should be fine.
